title: Ketan Patel

fields.name: Ketan Patel
fields.known_for: Co-founder and CEO of Greater Pacific Capital; chair of the Force for Good Initiative; writings on geopolitics, technology and capital allocation
fields.alma_mater: London School of Economics; City University Business School (MBA)
fields.organization: Greater Pacific Capital; Force for Good Initiative

lead:
'''Ketan Patel''' is a finance executive, investor and author. He is the chief executive and co-founder of the private equity firm ''Greater Pacific Capital'' (GPC) and chair of the Force for Good Initiative, an organization that publishes research and reports on capital allocation, technology, and sustainable development.<ref name="R144" /><ref name="R146" /><ref name="R147" /><ref name="R178" />

Patel is the author of ''The Master Strategist'' (2005) and has published articles on great-power transitions, sustainable development finance and global systemic risk in outlets including ''Frontiers in Political Science'' and ''Cadmus''.<ref name="R145" /><ref name="R174" /><ref name="R161" /><ref name="R176" />

sections.heading: Early life and education
sections.wikitext: In a 2005 profile, ''The Independent'' reported that Patel studied at the London School of Economics and City University Business School.<ref name="R58" /> Greater Pacific Capital's website states that he earned a BSc in Economics from the London School of Economics and an MBA from City University Business School, and describes him as a qualified accountant; it also states that he holds a postgraduate degree in neuroscience from King's College London.<ref name="R62" />

sections.heading: Career
sections.wikitext:
After qualifying as an accountant, Patel worked at KPMG and later joined Goldman Sachs.<ref name="R58" /> In May 2005, ''The Independent'' reported that he had recently left Goldman Sachs, where he had been head of strategy, to establish his own consultancy and investment business.<ref name="R58" />

Patel is the chief executive and co-founder of the private equity firm Greater Pacific Capital (GPC).<ref name="R144" /><ref name="R147" /> Media coverage of GPC has included reporting on the firm's India-focused fundraise and portfolio investments in education technology, electric vehicles and artificial intelligence.<ref name="R147" /><ref name="R150" /><ref name="R151" /><ref name="R153" />

He also chairs the Force for Good Initiative, which publishes research on capital allocation and technology in relation to sustainable development and human security.<ref name="R146" /><ref name="R178" /><ref name="R179" /> The initiative's ''Capital as a Force for Good'' report series analyzes sustainability-linked activity in the financial sector and has been covered by the International Institute for Sustainable Development's SDG Knowledge Hub.<ref name="R178" /><ref name="R180" />

In a conversation hosted by the London School of Economics' LSE IDEAS program, Patel described Force for Good as using the UN Sustainable Development Goals as a benchmark to assess global capital flows and identify potential solutions aimed at increasing investment in areas of need, including in the Global South.<ref name="Rq7P830q08VY" />

Patel has served as a trustee of the World Academy of Art and Science and has published with its journal ''Cadmus''.<ref name="R176" />

sections.heading: Ideas and contributions
sections.wikitext:
Patel's published work has focused on systemic risk and transition in the international order, with particular emphasis on the interaction of geopolitics, technology and capital allocation.

===Great-power transitions and the international order===
In a peer-reviewed article in ''Frontiers in Political Science'', Patel and co-authors argued that major powers tend to pass through identifiable life-cycle phases and assessed implications for U.S. strategic positioning and alliance structures.<ref name="R174" />

In a 2023 lecture hosted in the Lord Mayor's "Knowledge Miles" series at Gresham College, Patel framed the early 21st century as a period of overlapping transitions—including demographic growth, a shift toward multipolarity, and changes in technology and labor markets—and argued that these shifts would affect trade, capital, population, information and energy flows.<ref name="R186" />

In a panel discussion hosted by the World Academy of Art and Science, Patel described contemporary "global turbulence" in terms of multiple long-run "cycles" operating simultaneously, including climate cycles, shifts in economic eras (from industrial to information/technology), and changes in global power structures.<ref name="R189" />

In a 2020 SALT interview series hosted by SALT, Patel argued that historical empires tend to follow recurring rise-and-fall patterns and discussed the possibility of the United States moving from a period of predominance toward a shared-power system. In the same interview, he described what he called a "quadrilateral" structure of major power blocs—framed around the United States, China, India and the European Union—and argued that their interaction would increasingly shape global trade and rules-setting.<ref name="R194" />

In a panel discussion on investment opportunities along the "New Silk Road", Patel characterized the initiative as linking Europe and Asia through both physical and digital infrastructure and argued that investors assess countries across the corridor according to factors including the enforceability of law, currency convertibility, and sectoral regulatory ground rules.<ref name="R195" />

===Sustainable development finance and capital allocation===
In ''Cadmus'', Patel and co-authors argued that meeting the UN Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) is constrained less by the absolute availability of capital than by capital allocation mechanisms, incentives and risk pricing.<ref name="R161" /> Stefan Brunnhuber later described the paper as a "seminal" and "highly novel" contribution in an article responding to it.<ref name="R184" />

In a 2022 keynote address at an "SDG Investment Fair", Patel argued that SDG-related projects are often treated as "worthy causes" rather than commercial opportunities, and that investor concerns (including currency, regulatory, execution, exit and ESG-related risks) can raise required returns and limit capital flows to lower-income countries.<ref name="R187" />

In a panel discussion on sustainability performance and metrics, Patel argued that global investable capital exists but is not structured to flow to areas of greatest need, and that risk–return incentives tend to steer investment toward established markets rather than lower-income countries. In the same discussion, he said his analysis at Force for Good includes the geography and sectoral distribution of SDG-related finance and argued that technology solutions are being developed and deployed unevenly, with lower adoption in parts of the Global South.<ref name="RBJOuimJlSs4" />

In a panel at SALT on sustainability and capital allocation, Patel framed SDG financing as partly an investment opportunity tied to the inclusion of underserved populations and argued that technology can lower the cost of serving those markets.<ref name="R196" />

In a panel discussion on financing implementation of the SDGs hosted by the World Academy of Art and Science as part of its "Global Leadership for the 21st Century" series, Patel argued that there is no "lack of money" globally, but that financing depends on regulation and incentives, standard-setting to reduce "SDG-washing", and innovation in instruments (including debt-related tools).<ref name="RvdNREXocbJs" />

In an ICSD 2022 plenary session on financing implementation of the SDGs and the European Green Deal, Patel said his analysis at Force for Good suggested SDG financing requirements and the SDG financing gap had increased compared with earlier estimates, and argued that capital-allocation changes would require alignment among households, governments, the financial sector and corporations. He also said Force for Good's research found an association between more extensive sustainability activity and higher shareholder returns (as presented in the session).<ref name="Ro4g_83HuXJ0" />

===Energy transition, externalities and future energy systems===
In a COP29-related interview clip published by Force for Good, Patel argued that current accounting and market pricing does not fully incorporate environmental externalities, and suggested that regulators determine rules for pricing such costs.<ref name="R188" /> In the same interview, he described fossil fuels as having enabled industrial prosperity but argued that an immediate shut-off would be destabilizing, and said he expected a further breakthrough toward a clean and abundant energy source within "the next decade" or "decade and a half".<ref name="R188" />

In a COP29 dialogue session on innovation for climate and sustainability action, Patel discussed the role of incentives in capital allocation and, using India as an example, argued that investors see the country as having underlying macroeconomic "drivers" including urbanization, changing income distribution, and increasing internet use (as stated in the discussion).<ref name="IzWgfBIiaZ4" /> In the same panel, he argued that investor returns in India have been difficult to achieve consistently because, in his view, the pool of managers with differentiated capabilities is relatively limited and market volatility can be high; he said that protecting capital and managing risk were important factors for limited partners selecting managers (as stated in the discussion).<ref name="IzWgfBIiaZ4" />

In a COP29 dialogue session on innovation for climate and sustainability action, Patel argued that climate policy faced constraints in public and electoral politics and said that, in his reading of the IPCC reports, existing policies did not put the world on track to limit warming to 2.5 °C. In the same discussion, he said the financial system was structured to serve only part of the global population and argued that investment into lower-income markets is constrained by investor assessments of regulatory stability, currency controls, and exit/liquidity conditions (as stated in the session).<ref name="Rezd cZ5AsFdc" />

===Artificial intelligence and investment===
In a 2023 panel discussion about whether investment in AI resembled a bubble, Patel argued that AI was "foundational" rather than a short-term bubble, and described the technology as a hybrid of human and machine capabilities (which he termed "augmented" intelligence rather than "artificial" intelligence).<ref name="RSLzI6WBvUnw" /> In the same discussion, he argued that current AI systems were better described as tools for searching and structuring information than as systems with human-like contextual understanding or emotion, while also describing the technology as economically transformative and widely applicable across sectors including healthcare, education, financial services and research (as stated in the panel).<ref name="RSLzI6WBvUnw" />

===Global turbulence and polycrisis frameworks===
In 2025, Patel co-authored a series of ''Cadmus'' articles proposing conceptual frameworks for understanding "global turbulence" and policy responses to interlinked crises across security, development and governance.<ref name="R176" /><ref name="R175" />

===Cognitive sovereignty and information-era security===
A 2025 SSRN preprint by Patel examined what it termed "cognitive empires" and the strategic implications of algorithmic influence and AI systems for autonomy and security.<ref name="R177" />

===Technology and development pathways===
In Force for Good reports, Patel and collaborators have argued that digital technologies could materially accelerate progress toward sustainable development targets when paired with governance and investment frameworks.<ref name="R179" /><ref name="R180" />

In a panel on global trade and investment "megatrends", Patel argued that recent shocks had reduced the usefulness of extrapolating past trends in planning, and that large, apparently isolated events could substantially reshape capital flows and priorities, including financing for the SDGs.<ref name="R191" />

In a 2023 conference session on "education for human security" (World Academy of Art and Science), Patel presented the Human Security for All campaign as an attempt to translate the UN Sustainable Development Goals into a more accessible framework. He described the campaign in terms of seven "pillars"—food security, healthcare, economic security, environmental protection, personal safety and mobility, community security, and political freedom—and argued that a simpler framing could help technology firms and other organizations connect their activities to human-security outcomes.<ref name="RAM4p8kAazg8" />

In the same session, Patel argued that technology could help expand access to education and other services, and said that "40" SDG targets could be addressed through technology transfer; he cited UNICEF work on providing internet-like access to education in remote areas as an example of implementation approaches discussed in the session.<ref name="RAM4p8kAazg8" />

In a separate talk on the "future of money", Patel argued that the "character" of capital depends on its sources and associated obligations, and that the digitization of finance can disintermediate traditional institutions and enable more peer-to-peer transactions. He also argued that political debates framed as "socialism" versus "capitalism" were less descriptive of how money functions in an information-era context, and described digitization as expanding the range of assets and services that can be monetized and traded.<ref name="RfsbiQ5Y9j2E" />

In a 2025 CES panel discussion on technology and the developing world, Patel argued that falling technology costs and profit incentives would push firms toward "new markets" and "new customers", and that policy and cultural context can affect adoption. In the same discussion, he cited India's digital identity-linked system as an example of technology-enabled financial inclusion, describing it as enabling hundreds of millions of people to open bank accounts over several years (as stated in the panel).<ref name="R4sXj29SkAA8" />

In a 2025 CES interview focused on Force for Good's technology report, Patel described what he called a "fierce competition" among states in technology development, arguing that leadership in key technologies tends to correlate with geopolitical influence. In the same interview, he said Force for Good's research identified "19 technologies" that were ready to deploy and argued that practical barriers—including market size, governance, regulatory constraints for investors, and currency convertibility—can slow adoption in lower-income markets.<ref name="R193" />

===Risk, insurance and resilience===
In a recorded interview for a series on "the future of capitalism", Patel discussed risk and resilience with Bruce Carnegie-Brown (chairman of Lloyd's of London). In the interview, Patel raised risks associated with climate change and climate-driven migration, and argued that a substantial share of the Sustainable Development Goals financing gap could potentially be reduced through the transfer and application of existing technologies.<ref name="bGYwvYotujQ" />

sections.heading: Influence and reception
sections.wikitext:
Publisher material for ''The Master Strategist'' includes endorsement quotations attributed to Nelson Mandela and Nandan Nilekani.<ref name="R181" /><ref name="R182" /> A review of the book appeared in the ''IMFO'' journal (Institute of Municipal Finance Officers).<ref name="R185" />

In academic and policy-adjacent forums, Patel's work on SDG finance has been cited by other authors in ''Cadmus''; for example, Stefan Brunnhuber described Patel and co-authors' SDG-financing paper as "seminal" and "highly novel" in an article responding to its argument.<ref name="R184" />

In a 2023 introduction to a Lord Mayor's "Knowledge Miles" lecture, the session chair described Patel as "a senior figure in the City of London" and introduced him as chief executive and co-founder of Greater Pacific Capital and founder and chairman of Force for Good.<ref name="R186" />

In an LSE IDEAS discussion, the moderator introduced Patel as chair of Force for Good, a former head of Goldman Sachs' Strategic Group, and a co-founder of Greater Pacific Capital.<ref name="Rq7P830q08VY" />

In a 2019 conference panel introduction, the moderator introduced Patel as "CEO and Founder" of Greater Pacific Capital.<ref name="R195" />

In a 2025 CES panel on technology and the developing world, a panelist (Walt Stinson) referred to Patel's "Force for Good" group as having published a technology report and described it as a "132-page" report intended to inform industry planning (as stated in the discussion).<ref name="R4sXj29SkAA8" />

In a 2025 CES interview, the interviewer described Patel as leading "Force for Good" and "Pacific Capital" (in reference to Greater Pacific Capital).<ref name="R193" />

At the opening of a 2023 World Academy of Art and Science online conference session, the moderator introduced Patel as "co-founder and CEO" of Greater Pacific Capital and chair of Force for Good.<ref name="RAM4p8kAazg8" />

sections.heading: Personal life
sections.wikitext: A 2005 profile in ''The Independent'' noted that Patel lived in London and described his interest in meditation and long-distance running.<ref name="R58" />

sections.heading: Selected works
sections.wikitext:
* ''The Master Strategist: Power, Purpose and Principle'' (Hutchinson, 2005).<ref name="R145" /><ref name="R183" />
* ''The Master Strategist: Power, Purpose and Principle in Action'' (Arrow, 2007).<ref name="R181" /><ref name="R183" />
* ''The Master Strategist'' (Cornerstone Digital, e-book, 2011).<ref name="R182" />
* "American hegemony at a critical juncture, lessons from history's great powers" (with Christian Hansmeyer, Nandan Desai and Aditya Ajit), ''Frontiers in Political Science'' (2025).<ref name="R174" />
* "Funding the Sustainable Development Goals is Not a Challenge of Sufficient Capital" (with Christian Hansmeyer, Nandan Desai and Aditya Ajit), ''Cadmus'' (2025).<ref name="R161" />
* "Sources and Solutions for Global Turbulence" (with Garry Jacobs), ''Cadmus'' (2025).<ref name="R176" />
* "Turbulent Times: A Framework for Navigating Global Crisis Through Conscious Transformation" (with Christian Hansmeyer), ''Cadmus'' (2025).<ref name="R175" />
* "The Rising Age of Cognitive Empires: Colonising the Mind" (preprint), SSRN (2025).<ref name="R177" />

sections.heading: Further reading
sections.wikitext:
* Nissel, Jason (29 May 2005). "Ketan Patel and Thomas Friedman: Just stop the world, so the West can get off". ''The Independent''.<ref name="R58" />
* "Greater Pacific Capital hits first close of $300 million in $700 million India-focused fund". ''Mint'' (6 August 2018).<ref name="R147" />
* "UN faces US$100t shortfall in fight against climate change, inequality". ''The Business Times'' (17 September 2021).<ref name="R144" />
* "Force for Good report explores role of technology in helping reach SDGs". SDG Knowledge Hub (International Institute for Sustainable Development) (2 February 2023).<ref name="R180" />

external_links.label: SSRN author listing (The Rising Age of Cognitive Empires)

notability_signals: Named as CEO/co-founder of Greater Pacific Capital in business press coverage (e.g., Mint; The Business Times)
Chair and project lead of Force for Good report series; covered by SDG Knowledge Hub (International Institute for Sustainable Development)
Peer-reviewed publication in Frontiers in Political Science (2025)
Publisher pages include endorsement quotations from prominent public figures for The Master Strategist
gaps_to_fill: Birth date, birthplace and nationality from reliable independent sources (required for BLP completeness).
At least two additional substantial independent profiles (major newspaper/magazine/industry profile pieces) synthesizing Patel’s career and influence, beyond deal and event coverage.
Independent, reputable coverage of the Force for Good Initiative’s governance and real-world impact (beyond its own reports).

Verification of any claim that The Master Strategist contains a foreword by Nelson Mandela via book front matter or an authoritative bibliographic record (publisher pages currently provide endorsement quotations only).
Precise dates and transcript/page anchors for cited conference appearances (e.g., SALT conference session) where used for claims.
Outcome verification sources for Patel's COP29-era energy-technology prediction (breakthrough toward clean, abundant energy within a decade to 15 years).

Missing upload/publication dates and hosting-organization metadata for YouTube sources used as citations (Gresham/Lord Mayor lecture; SDG Investment Fair keynote; COP29 clip), to support precise dating and event-context attribution.

Missing upload/publication dates and hosting-organization metadata for YouTube sources used as citations for WAAS panels ("Does History have a Direction"; "Root Causes and Deep Drivers of Global Social Turbulence"), and for the global trade/investment megatrends panel, to support precise dating and context attribution.

Missing upload/publication dates and hosting-organization metadata for YouTube sources used as citations for (a) CES interview (CU2nlM0Pyxc) and (b) WAAS global financial reform panel (PrQG-ixeDy8), to support precise dating and context attribution.

Transcript verification needed for any quantitative claims made in talks (e.g., '250 trillion' in markets; GDP-share figures; '165 million people fall into poverty since 2020'; '19 technologies ready'; '$15 trillion opportunity') before using them beyond attributed statements.

Missing upload/publication dates and hosting-organization metadata for YouTube sources used as citations for (a) WAAS 'Education for Human Security' inaugural session (AM4p8kAazg8) and (b) 'The Nature of Money' talk (fsbiQ5Y9j2E), to support precise dating and event-context attribution.

Needs transcript verification (and preferably independent corroboration) for Patel's quantified claim that '40' SDG targets could be addressed through technology transfer; current support is only an attributed statement in a conference transcript.

Missing upload date, channel/organization, and episode metadata for the LSE IDEAS video 'Lord Mayor Michael Mainelli, London' (q7P830q08VY), and confirmation of the event date and full speaker list as shown on the video page.

Missing upload date, hosting-organization metadata, and conference/year context for YouTube video 'Rise of the East: Investment Opportunities on the New Silk Road' (Z2YsxpHQez4) used for Patel's remarks about the 'New Silk Road'.

Missing upload date, hosting-organization metadata, and event context for YouTube video 'Capital as a Force for Good: Investing for Impact and Returns | #SALTNY' (vXiOrcfPAcI) used for Patel's SDG-finance remarks.

Missing upload/publication date and hosting-organization metadata for YouTube video 'Leadership for financing implementation of the SDGs | Global Leadership for the 21st Century' (vdNREXocbJs) used for Patel's SDG-finance remarks.

Missing upload date, channel/organization, and program/episode metadata for the LSE IDEAS video 'Lord Mayor Michael Mainelli, London' (q7P830q08VY), and confirmation of the event date and full speaker list as shown on the video page.

Missing upload date, channel/organization, and event metadata for the video 'International Conference on Sustainable Cities | Ketan Patel' (XxL8bEEoq6c), including host organization and conference date.

Missing upload/publication date, channel/organization, and event metadata for CES panel video 'What are the Technology Needs for the Developing World?' (4sXj29SkAA8), including confirmation that Patel is the moderator/speaker and the panel date (as shown on the YouTube page).

Missing upload date, channel/organization, and event metadata for the video 'Innovative Technologies as a Force for Good | WAAS@64 | May 16, 2024' (5B_GyzqWkvI) if used beyond self-identification; most content is other panelists' remarks.

Missing upload date, channel/organization, and event metadata for the COP29 video 'Day 1 Session 1: High-level session on Innovation for Climate and Sustainability Action' (ezdcZ5AsFdc), including confirmation of event date and host channel.

Outcome verification sources for Patel-attributed AI economic-impact figures referenced in the AI-bubble panel (e.g., job displacement and GDP impact estimates), if they are to be used beyond attributed remarks.

Missing upload/publication date, channel/organization, and event metadata for YouTube video 'Incredible India: How to Identify Opportunities Amid Dispersion' (IzWgfBIiaZ4), including conference name and date (as shown on the YouTube page).

Reviewed transcript (Education on Existential Risks to Human Security | Education for Human Security | Mar 7-9, 2023) does not include verifiable remarks by Ketan Patel; if Patel appears elsewhere in the same conference, a timecoded transcript segment identifying him is needed before inclusion.

revision_log.run_summary: Reviewed 5 transcript items. The provided batch contained 1 transcript (lPV2c8EkayQ) and no additional items. This transcript is a panel on education and existential risks featuring multiple speakers (Mike, David, Ortwin, Thomas, Monif) and contains no identifiable remarks by Ketan Patel; therefore no article text was added or modified. Logged as reviewed/unused and added a gaps_to_fill note about needing a Patel-specific segment if relevant.
added: Added one gaps_to_fill item documenting that the reviewed transcript did not contain identifiable Ketan Patel remarks and would require a timecoded segment to use.

quote_bank.quote_text: If you add to the purpose of every tech company, all of a sudden you have a moral purpose, you have something that could be hugely profitable, because your technology reaches a customer base that (previously) was not profitable.
quote_bank.speaker: Ketan Patel
quote_bank.speaker_credential: Described by Reuters as running the Force for Good Foundation
quote_bank.context: Quoted by Reuters in a report on CES adopting a social theme.

quote_bank.quote_text: A series of interlinked crises, from armed conflicts and energy shocks to deglobalization, climate change, and economic turbulence, risk negatively impacting the global economy, geopolitical stability, and societies across the world.
quote_bank.speaker: Technology as a Force for Good report (Force for Good Initiative)
quote_bank.context: Report framing of polycrisis and systemic transition.

quote_bank.quote_text: Technology can reduce the cost of achieving the SDGs by as much as USD 55 trillion, enabling 103 of the 169 SDG targets.
quote_bank.speaker: SDG Knowledge Hub (IISD) summary of Force for Good report
quote_bank.context: Independent coverage summarizing Force for Good report claims.

quote_bank.quote_text: Brunnhuber described the SDG-financing paper by Patel and co-authors as "seminal" and "highly novel".
quote_bank.speaker: Stefan Brunnhuber
quote_bank.context: Response article discussing SDG financing argument.

quote_bank.quote_text: Today we have a really interesting topic Capital as a powerful force for Global impact—we're delighted to have Ketan Patel with us today he's a senior figure in the city of London having held positions with Goldman Sachs KPMG and hulic Packard today he is the CEO and co-founder of Greater Pacific Capital as well as the founder and chairman of Force for good.
quote_bank.speaker: Tim Connell
quote_bank.speaker_credential: Session chair (Gresham College / Knowledge Miles series introduction)
quote_bank.context: Introduction to Patel's lecture in the Lord Mayor's lectures / Knowledge Miles series.

quote_bank.quote_text: kitan Patel is chair of the Force for good initiative ... he's a former head of Goldman Sachs strategic group and co-founder of Greater Pacific Capital
quote_bank.speaker: Mary Martin
quote_bank.speaker_credential: Director, UN Business and Human Security Initiative at LSE IDEAS (as stated in the discussion introduction)
quote_bank.context: Moderator introduction of Patel in an LSE IDEAS discussion about financial centres and societal challenges.

claim_ledger.claim: Patel is CEO and co-founder of Greater Pacific Capital.
Patel chairs the Force for Good Initiative.
Patel studied at the London School of Economics and City University Business School.
Patel and co-authors published a peer-reviewed article in Frontiers in Political Science on U.S. hegemony and lessons from historical great powers.
Patel and co-authors argued in Cadmus that SDG financing is constrained by allocation mechanisms rather than absolute capital availability.

In a Lord Mayor / Knowledge Miles lecture, Patel framed the early 21st century as overlapping transitions (demographics, multipolarity, technology and labor-market change) affecting trade, capital, population, information and energy flows.

In a 2022 SDG Investment Fair keynote, Patel argued SDG projects are often treated as worthy causes rather than business opportunities, and that investor risks (currency, regulatory, execution, exit and ESG) can constrain capital flows to lower-income countries.

In a COP29-related interview clip, Patel argued environmental externalities are not fully priced in current accounting and market pricing and suggested regulators determine rules for pricing such costs; he also said an immediate switch-off of fossil fuels would cause chaos, and expected a clean, abundant energy breakthrough within 10–15 years.
In a WAAS panel discussion, Patel described several long-run cycles as converging, including climate cycles, shifts in economic eras, and cycles in global power structures.

In a panel on sustainable growth in the Gulf during the net-zero transition, Patel said large financial institutions use ESG criteria that can exclude certain types of investments and argued that applying those criteria could put hydrocarbon-dependent economies at a disadvantage; he suggested Gulf states could respond by funding the UN Sustainable Development Goals.

In a panel on global trade and investment megatrends, Patel argued that recent disruptive events reduce the usefulness of extrapolating past trends in planning and can reshape capital flows, including toward SDG-related financing.

In a WAAS panel on global financial reform, Patel characterized modern global capital markets as shaped by an "industrial and colonial" model of capitalism and argued that changing accounting to price environmental externalities more fully would change investment incentives.

In a CES interview about Force for Good's technology report, Patel argued that technology development is a field of geopolitical competition among states and that barriers (including market size for infrastructure, governance and regulatory constraints, and currency convertibility) can inhibit rollout of existing technologies in lower-income markets.

In a 2023 WAAS 'education for human security' session, Patel described the Human Security for All framework as comprising seven pillars: food security, healthcare, economic security, environmental protection, personal safety and mobility, community security, and political freedom.
In the same session, Patel said that a portion of SDG targets could be addressed through technology transfer and gave an estimate of "40" targets (as stated in the transcript).

In a talk on the future of money, Patel argued that money has a 'character' affected by its sources and obligations, and that digitization can disintermediate institutions and expand peer-to-peer transactions and monetization of assets and services.

In an interview with Lloyd's of London chairman Bruce Carnegie-Brown, Patel raised climate risks and associated population movements and argued that the SDG financing gap could be substantially reduced through application of existing technologies.

In a panel discussion on sustainability performance and metrics, Patel argued that while global capital is sufficient in aggregate, market incentives steer it toward established profitable markets rather than areas of highest need; he also said Force for Good analyzes where SDG-related finance flows by SDG and by country and argued that technology solutions are being deployed unevenly, with lower adoption in parts of the Global South.

In a 2020 SALT Talks interview, Patel argued that empires follow a rise-and-fall pattern and discussed a shift toward shared power among major blocs; he described a 'quadrilateral' structure of major power blocs framed around the United States, China, India and the European Union.

In a panel discussion on investment opportunities along the "New Silk Road", Patel argued that investors look for rule of law/enforceability, currency transferability/convertibility, and clear industry ground rules for regulation when evaluating markets across the corridor.

In a SALT panel on sustainability and investing, Patel argued that SDG-related investment can be framed as an opportunity tied to serving excluded populations, and that technology can lower the cost of serving such markets.

In a WAAS-hosted panel discussion on financing implementation of the SDGs, Patel argued that SDG financing is a systemic issue requiring regulation and incentives, robust standards to reduce 'SDG-washing', and financial-instrument innovation.

In an LSE IDEAS discussion, Patel described Force for Good as using the UN Sustainable Development Goals as a benchmark to assess capital flows (including toward the Global South) and to identify potential solutions to bridge gaps.

In an ICSD 2022 plenary session on financing the SDGs and the European Green Deal, Patel said SDG spending requirements and the SDG financing gap had increased (as presented in the session) and argued that closing the gap would require alignment across households, governments, the finance industry and corporations; he also presented an association between more extensive sustainability activity and higher shareholder returns.

In a CES panel on technology needs in the developing world, Patel argued that market incentives and falling technology costs would drive firms to seek new markets, but that policy choices and cultural understanding affect technology adoption. In the same discussion, he cited an India-based digital identity-linked system as an example of technology-enabled financial inclusion (as stated in the panel).

In a CES panel on technology needs in the developing world, panelist Walt Stinson referred to a Force for Good technology report and described it as a 132-page report intended to help strategic planners (as stated in the panel).

In a panel discussion about AI investment and bubbles, Patel said he viewed AI as 'augmented' intelligence (a hybrid of human and machine), argued that AI was 'foundational' rather than a short-term bubble, and stated that current systems primarily search and structure information rather than exhibit human contextual understanding or emotion (as stated in the panel).

In a COP29 dialogue session on innovation for climate and sustainability action, Patel said climate change was not a prominent feature of voter choices in many countries holding elections that year, and argued that there was insufficient political will for large-scale climate-related change (as stated in the session).
In the same COP29 dialogue session, Patel said that, in his reading of IPCC reports, current policies implied the world had no chance of limiting warming to 2.5°C (as stated in the session).

In the same COP29 dialogue session, Patel argued that investment into lower-income markets faced higher perceived risks relative to investing in U.S. equities, citing factors such as currency controls, bureaucracy/regulatory constraints, and liquidity/exit conditions (as stated in the session).

In a conference panel on investment opportunities in India, Patel compared India's and China's GDP growth trajectories and argued that India's growth drivers included urbanization, demographic changes and rising adoption of digital technologies (as stated in the panel).

In the same India-focused panel, Patel argued that the ability of limited partners to realize consistent returns depends in part on manager selection and risk management; he said capital protection can be more important than opportunity identification in volatile markets (as stated in the panel).

prediction_bank.prediction_text: Patel said he believed an additional breakthrough toward an energy source that is "clean, abundant" and widely deployable would be made within "the next decade" or "decade and a half".
prediction_bank.context: COP29-related Force for Good interview clip about externalities pricing and the energy transition.

prediction_bank.prediction_text: In a New Silk Road panel discussion, Patel said that by 2050 Asia was expected to account for around 50–60% of global flows of trade, capital and economic output (as stated in the panel).
prediction_bank.context: Panel discussion on investment opportunities along the "New Silk Road"; statement given as a projection while describing long-run shifts toward Asia.
